event.doc_name: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.text: 1.  When the Affordable Care Act (ACA) was enacted in 2010, millions of Americans gained access to affordable, comprehensive health care for the first time.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The Affordable Care Act (ACA) was enacted in 2010, granting millions of Americans access to affordable, comprehensive health care for the first time.

evidence.text: 2.  The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), on behalf of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), has now published a final rule, purportedly pursuant to the ACA, whose effects will be directly contrary to that landmark legislation.  That rule—entitled “Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; Marketplace Integrity and Affordability” (2025 Rule), 90 Fed. Reg. 27,074—purports to “strengthen[] the integrity of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) eligibility and enrollment systems to reduce waste, fraud and abuse” and “provide emergent relief from rising improper enrollment and health care costs.”
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) published a final rule entitled "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; Marketplace Integrity and Affordability" (2025 Rule).

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA's health insurance Exchanges in 2026.

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will increase premiums and out‑of‑pocket costs for consumers.

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will reduce the ACA’s guaranteed‑issue requirement for individuals with past‑due premiums.

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will reduce the open‑enrollment period for Exchanges, making it shorter and more restrictive.

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will eliminate the low‑income special enrollment period (SEP).

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will impose a $5 penalty on automatic re‑enrollees in the Exchanges.

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will increase the premium adjustment percentage, raising the maximum annual out‑of‑pocket limit.

evidence.text: 3.  Rather than reducing the cost of insurance for consumers, or increasing their enrollment rates and benefits, Defendants’ new policies will cause at least 1.8 million Americans to lose coverage on the ACA’s health insurance Exchanges in 2026 alone and will ultimately result in higher premiums in the long term and higher out-of-pocket costs for the remaining enrollees.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will reduce the actuarial value of coverage for consumers.

evidence.text: 62.  An increase in the number of uninsured and underinsured individuals will lead to a greater burden on the city’s services and lower reimbursement, which will impose additional costs on the city.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: The 2025 Rule will increase the number of uninsured and underinsured individuals, leading to higher EMS and health service costs for city governments.

evidence.text: Plaintiffs the City of Columbus, Ohio; the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore; Maryland; the City of Chicago, Illinois; Doctors for America; and Main Street Alliance hereby sue Defendants ...
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs include City of Columbus, Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, City of Chicago, Doctors for America, and Main Street Alliance.

evidence.text: Columbus, located in Franklin County, is the capital of Ohio. It is the largest city in the state and the fifteenth largest city in the United States, with a population of around 933,000, according to 2024 census estimates.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, the largest city in the state, and has a population of about 933,000.

evidence.text: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore represent the largest city in Maryland and thirtieth largest city in the United States, with a population of over 568,000, according to 2024 census estimates.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Baltimore is the largest city in Maryland, with a population of over 568,000.

evidence.text: City of Chicago, Illinois, is a municipal corporation and home‑rule unit organized and existing under the constitution and law of the state of Illinois. Located in Cook County, Chicago is the largest city in Illinois and the third‑largest city in the United States, with a population of over 2.7 million, according to 2024 census estimates.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Chicago is the largest city in Illinois and the third‑largest city in the United States, with a population of over 2.7 million.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Main Street Alliance (MSA) is 501(c)(3) organization and national network of small businesses, with approximately 30,000 small business members throughout the United States.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Main Street Alliance is a 501(c)(3) national network of small businesses with approximately 30,000 members throughout the United States.

evidence.text: Plaintiff Doctors for America (DFA) is a not‑for‑profit, § 501(c)(3) organization with over 27,000 member physicians and medical trainees (including medical residents and students) in all 50 states.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Doctors for America is a not‑for‑profit organization with over 27,000 member physicians and medical trainees.
